prompt: Identify one key psychological or structural barrier that prevents people from expanding their moral concern to include factory-farmed animals. Propose a concrete intervention that could realistically shift behavior at scale, and justify why it would work. (Maximum two paragraphs.)

candidates.text:
One key psychological barrier limiting moral concern for factory-farmed animals is the cognitive dissonance arising from the compartmentalization of meat consumption and animal suffering—people separate their affection for pets or wild animals from the animals raised in industrial settings, often due to the physical and social distance created by the production system. This “moral disengagement” is reinforced by a lack of direct sensory or emotional engagement with these animals, who are rarely seen in their living conditions, reducing empathy and ethical concern.

A concrete and novel intervention to shift behavior at scale would be to integrate immersive, mixed-reality experiences showcasing the life cycles and environments of factory-farmed animals into everyday grocery shopping environments via augmented reality (AR) glasses or smartphone apps. Instead of activist campaigns or documentaries, shoppers could, while choosing products, instantly visualize a lifelike simulation of the animal’s experience, personalized to the exact product they hold. This real-time, context-specific moral salience disrupts compartmentalization by bringing otherwise abstract suffering into the immediate cognitive and emotional sphere. By embedding this into habitual consumer behavior at the point of purchase, it leverages convenience and immediacy to foster empathy, prompting gradual shifts in consumption patterns without relying on prior motivation or deliberate moral reflection—thus potentially scaling beyond activist reach and traditional education.

Because transit hubs serve millions regularly, this approach leverages scale and routine exposure to recalibrate automatic moral attitudes, fostering sustained moral expansion in a way that traditional messaging or activism cannot achieve.
